Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Computer Cluster for Computational Materials Research and Education at the University of South Florida and Partnering Institutions in Tampa Bay
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation Program (MRI) and support from the Chemistry Research Instrumentation Program (CRIF) the University of South Florida will acquire a computer cluster. The acquisition will enable graduate and undergraduate students to undertake computational research projects. Using theoretical methods coded into computer programs, they will provide insight on projects involving the development of novel materials for energy conversion, gas storage, sensors and catalysis and the development of new biomaterials with superior properties. The computer cluster will be a resource also used by students and faculty for research and education activities at the University of Tampa, Eckerd College, and New College and by other institutions in central Florida.

Specific research investigations to be undertaken will be in areas such as (a) modelling metal organic frameworks (MOFs) for capturing targeted gases to understand gas sorption mechanisms and dynamics; (b) designing novel materials and predicting their structural, electronic, and mechanical properties; (c) investigating biosensors, plasmonics and computational catalysis; (d) using titanium dioxide catalysts for splitting water; (e) calculating interface specific sum frequency vibrational spectroscopy (SFVS) spectra from time correlation functions and instantaneous normal modes; and many other projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This MRI award supported the purchase of a large computer cluster that supported a broad portfolio of research projects in materials science and engineering across 4 institutions and 17 research groups. The intellectual merit of the project was the use of the purchased cluster for large-scale, advanced computer modeling to aid the development of new materials with useful properties and help the understanding of complex materials. The cluster was used to develop new materials for gas sorption, gas separation, gas storage, cooling and catalysis, carbon conversion and sensing, to discover new energy-rich materials and to explain and understand the structure and properties of spider silk, collagen, and other biomaterials. The award resulted in more than 100 published and submitted peer-reviewed research papers, and significantly bolstered the research and educational capabilities of the University of South Florida, The University of Tampa, Eckerd College, and New College of Florida. The broader impacts of the project were a significant advance in the capabilities of theory and materials simulation, the training of 4 postdocs, 51 graduate students and 49 undergraduate students in computational sciences and engineering, and the computational support to experimental research groups. In addition, annual day long computational workshops were organized for undergraduate students across the four partnering institutions.
